lesson_html:
Booleans in Python are similar to C# boolean values, represented by the keywords True and False (note the capital first letters, just like in C#).

Comparison operators in Python work very similarly to C#:

  • ==: Equality comparison (same as C#)
  • !=: Inequality comparison (same as C#)
  • <: Less than (same as C#)
  • >: Greater than (same as C#)
  • <=: Less than or equal to (same as C#)
  • >=: Greater than or equal to (same as C#)

Logical operators are also very similar to C#:

  • and: Logical AND (equivalent to C#'s &&)
  • or: Logical OR (equivalent to C#'s ||)
  • not: Logical NOT (equivalent to C#'s !)

Example of boolean operations:

x = 5
y = 10

# Comparison examples
print(x < y)  # True
print(x == y)  # False
print(x != y)  # True

# Logical operations
print(x < y and x > 0)  # True
print(x > y or x == 5)  # True
print(not (x == y))  # True

from solution import is_valid_triangle

def test_valid_triangle():
    assert is_valid_triangle(3, 4, 5) == True, "Classic 3-4-5 triangle should be valid"
    assert is_valid_triangle(1, 1, 3) == False, "Triangle with impossible side lengths"
    assert is_valid_triangle(5, 5, 5) == True, "Equilateral triangle should be valid"

def test_invalid_triangle():
    assert is_valid_triangle(0, 4, 5) == False, "Triangle cannot have zero-length side"
    assert is_valid_triangle(-1, 2, 3) == False, "Triangle cannot have negative side lengths"
